Award.AwardTitle: Scholastic Excellence Scholarships in Computer Information Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: A goal of this project is to attract new students to the Computer Information Systems (CIS) program at the University of Louisville by providing financial and academic support. The main objectives are to increase the number of students entering the CIS program and to recruit students from underrepresented groups for careers in computer science. The scholars are selected by a committee of professors and specialists in financial aid, admissions, advising, and mentoring. The university has in place numerous proactive student support services such as REACH (REsources for academic ACHievement), Reinhardt Academic Center, Ulmer Career Management Center, and Disability Resource Center. The program also offers a one-week pre-college summer workshop highlighting the CIS program content, including hands on lab activities.

Institution.Name: University of Louisville Research Foundation Inc

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this grant - 'Scholastic Excellence Scholarships in Computer Information Systems' - was to attract more students, especially minority and female students, to the Computer Information Systems (CIS) major, a STEM discipline, in the College of Business at the University of Louisville. Specifically, the grant provided renewable scholarships to undergraduate students who choose to major in CIS in order to: (1) increase the number of students entering the CIS program, (2) improve retention rates of the CIS program, (3) recruit minority and female students to the CIS program, and (4) provide dedicated student support services for scholarship recipients.

Over the course of the grant (07/01/2010 - 06/30/2016), 38 students were supported with scholarships totaling $485,466. Of these students, 24% were female and 76% were male. Reported races among these students included 79% white, 10% black or African American, 5% Asian, 3% American Indian or Alaska native, and 8% did not report race (or was unknown). 8% of these students designated a Hispanic or Latino ethnicity and 3% did not report (or was unknown). 11% of the scholarship recipients reported having a disability and 26% did not report (or was unknown).  Please note, numbers do not add up to 100% because students may report more than one race/ethnicity.

All of the CIS Scholastic Excellence Scholarship students were invited to meet with the PI during the grant period. The students' academic performance was reviewed and progress in the major was discussed, including course scheduling. Students that were in need of assistance were offered tutoring and other services (such as counseling). To help recruit students into the program, the PI met with interested high school computer science faculty and participated on an Advisory Board for a local high school computer science program.

Of the 38 supported scholarship students, 20 (53%) graduated with the CIS major while they were part of the program, another 9 (24%) graduated after their scholarship's ended, and 4 (11%) are on track to graduate after the program ends. That means that nearly 87% of the scholarship students graduated with a CIS undergraduate degree or are on track to do so. This is a considerably higher graduation rate than the CIS major and University, generally. Only 5 (13%) students left the CIS major at UofL, transferred to another school, or stopped attending.

In conclusion, the scholarships provided through this generous grant have enabled many students to either begin, continue, or complete their studies in Computer Information Systems, a STEM discipline, on a full-time basis. Many of the students have expressed a great amount of gratitude for the scholarship given their financial need. Even those that ultimately switched majors will have received financial support that has furthered their progress towards an undergraduate degree.

Respectfully submitted,

Dr. Andrew Wright
Assistant Professor of Computer Information Systems
University of Louisville
College of Business
Louisville, KY 40292


Last Modified: 08/12/2016
Modified by: Andrew Wright
